image.altText: CLP leader Lia Finocchiaro standing in front of NT Parliament House and looking serious.

items.synopsis: Follow our live coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Thursday, October 12.

title.children: NT leader says alternatives to Voice being prepped, Indigenous man turned away from polls over Yes shirt

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Matt Garrick The Northern Territory's Opposition Leader, Lia Finocchiaro, says she doesn't believe a Voice to Parliament will deliver change for remote NT communities and is confident a No vote will prevail in the territory. Speaking at a press conference, Ms Finocchiaro says her party, the Country Liberals, is preparing policies for the 2024 NT election to help "re-empower" the NT's remote communities, through "restoring community control of local government". "A CLP government that I lead is very committed to Aboriginal people living in the bush, in restoring, literally, their voice to our parliament," she said. "Local government reform is critical, and so we're out engaging … about how we can reshape local government to give back that decision-making and that voice in our remote communities." At a Yes campaign on Wednesday in Alice Springs, Chief Minister Natasha Fyles criticised Ms Finocchiaro's council plan, and said she was "simply making excuses" for voting against a Voice.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NT opposition leader says alternatives to Voice being prepared

children.content: NT opposition leader Lia Finocchiaro is spruiking alternatives to the Voice.
(ABC News: Michael Franchi)
Reporting by Matt Garrick
The Northern Territory's Opposition Leader,
Lia Finocchiaro
, says she doesn't believe a Voice to Parliament will deliver change for remote NT communities and is confident a
No vote will prevail in the territory
Speaking at a press conference, Ms Finocchiaro says her party, the
Country Liberals
, is preparing policies for the 2024 NT election to help "re-empower" the NT's remote communities, through "restoring community control of local government".
"A CLP government that I lead is very committed to Aboriginal people living in the bush, in restoring, literally, their voice to our parliament," she said.
"Local government reform is critical, and so we're out engaging … about how we can reshape local government to give back that decision-making and that voice in our remote communities."
At a Yes campaign on Wednesday in Alice Springs,
Chief Minister Natasha Fyles
criticised Ms Finocchiaro's council plan, and said she was "simply making excuses" for voting against a Voice.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Yagara and Bundjalung elder, Uncle Valentine Brown, attended the Winston Glades polling station near Ipswich, west of Brisbane, on Tuesday. The 73-year-old said when he entered the polling station, official workers told him he wasn't allowed to vote while wearing a Yes shirt, but did not give him an explanation as to why. He was told to go home and change clothes if he wanted to cast his ballot. "We were just going around peacefully, doing our business to vote," Mr Brown said. In a statement, a spokesperson encouraged voters to not wear campaign clothing, as the law states people cannot campaign within 6 metres of a polling station. "If a voter simply wears campaign material (ie a pin or shirt) into the polling place, casts their vote and leaves, it likely won't contravene the act," the AEC spokesperson said. "However, if the voter wears that material into a polling place and is then seen talking with someone inside about it … that could be construed as campaigning."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indigenous elder turned away from voting centre for wearing Yes shirt

featuredLink.title: Don't wear 'Yes' or 'No' clothing when you vote in the Voice referendum, AEC warns

children.content: Yagara elder Uncle Val says he was turned away from a polling booth in Ipswich
(ABC News: Victoria Pengilley)
Yagara and Bundjalung elder,
Uncle Valentine Brown
, attended the Winston Glades polling station near Ipswich, west of Brisbane, on Tuesday.
The 73-year-old said when he entered the polling station, official workers told him
he wasn't allowed to vote while wearing a Yes shirt, but did not give him an explanation as to why
He was told to go home and change clothes if he wanted to cast his ballot.
"We were just going around peacefully, doing our business to vote," Mr Brown said.
In a statement, a spokesperson encouraged voters to
not wear campaign clothing
, as the law states people cannot campaign within 6 metres of a polling station.
"If a voter simply wears campaign material (ie a pin or shirt) into the polling place, casts their vote and leaves, it likely won't contravene the act," the AEC spokesperson said.
"However, if the voter wears that material into a polling place and is then seen talking with someone inside about it … that could be construed as campaigning."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We will be bringing you the latest developments on the Voice to Parliament referendum as they happen today. Yesterday, "Father of reconciliation" Pat Dodson gave his National Press Club address, saying that a No result in the referendum would send the country backwards. Twenty-five Australians of the Year signed an open letter urging people around the country to vote Yes. Linda Burney called for Peter Dutton to apologise for his comments about late Northern Territory land rights giant Yunupiŋu. Former MP Pat Farmer completed his 14,000km journey around the country campaigning for the Yes vote. Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Welcome to our live coverage

children.content: We will be bringing you the latest developments on the

Stay tuned for the latest updates as they unfold today.

image.altText: People are watching a fire burn on top of the rubble of a residential building in Gaza.

items.synopsis: Israel cuts off Gaza's external electricity supply as part of its retaliation for the terror attacks perpetrated by Hamas in southern Israel over the weekend. Follow live.

title.children: Gaza power plant shuts down after running out of fuel

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israel's ambassador to the UK remains unapologetic over his country's bombardment of Gaza, warning there will be no quick fix to the crisis following the weekend's terror attack by Hamas. Speaking to ABC's Michael Rowland from Tel Aviv, Mark Regev said Saturday's attack was a declaration of war. "The way they invaded, they butchered our people, killing innocent people in their homes, murdering children, what they did was a strategic attack on my country and they started this war and we will finish it," he said. Mr Ragev said while civilian casualties should be avoided at any cost, there was no way of avoiding it in this case. "There hasn't been a war in recent history which hasn't involved collateral damage and civilians, unfortunately, getting killed," he said. "If we can't hit them back, why would they stop?" He added that Israel authorities were urging the civilian population of Gaza to move away from Hamas strongholds. "They aren't our target, it is the Hamas military leadership and political structure," he said. "That is the target. It is going to be a war and wars are messy and we will lose people ourselves." He said the sort of barbarism that was committed by Hamas on Saturday morning was "reminiscent of ISIS-type terrorism". "We can no longer have our civilian population exposed to the sorts of barbarism violence that Hamas is capable of," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israeli ambassador says Hamas attack  'reminiscent of ISIS-type terrorism'

mediaThumbnail.caption: Former Israeli Ambassador to the UK Mark Regev says Hamas attack was a declaration of war and warned of significant civilian casualties in Gaza as violence intensifies.

children.content: Israel's ambassador to the UK remains unapologetic over his country's bombardment of Gaza, warning there will be no quick fix to the crisis following the weekend's terror attack by Hamas.
Speaking to ABC's Michael Rowland from Tel Aviv, Mark Regev said Saturday's attack was a declaration of war.
"The way they invaded, they butchered our people, killing innocent people in their homes, murdering children, what they did was a strategic attack
on my country and they started this war and we will finish it," he said.
Mr Ragev said while civilian casualties should be avoided at any cost, there was no way of avoiding it in this case.
"There hasn't been a war in recent history which hasn't involved collateral damage and civilians, unfortunately, getting killed," he said.
"If we can't hit them back, why would they stop?"
He added that Israel authorities were urging the civilian population of Gaza to move away from Hamas strongholds.
"They aren't our target, it is the Hamas military leadership and political structure," he said.
"That is the target. It is going to be a war and wars are messy and we will lose people ourselves."
He said the sort of barbarism that was committed by Hamas on Saturday morning was "reminiscent of ISIS-type terrorism".
"We can no longer have our civilian population exposed to the sorts of barbarism violence that Hamas is capable of," he said.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) has released updated figures on deaths and injuries from the West Bank on Wednesday. It says up until 10pm local time (6am AEDT Thursday), one person had died, and 76 more were injured. While the war began in Israel's south on Saturday, clashes in the West Bank have intensified over recent days. The PRCS said that, of the injured, 27 came from live amunition, and eight were caused by rubber bullets. It also released a statement saying four paramedics had died in Gaza, as a result of air strikes. While the videos are too graphic to publish, this photo shows colleagues comforting each other on what was another devastating day in the Middle East.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: One dead, 76 injured in West Bank, says Red Crescent

children.content: The Palestinian Red Crescent Society (PRCS) has released updated figures on deaths and injuries from the West Bank on Wednesday.
It says up until 10pm local time (6am AEDT Thursday), one person had died, and 76 more were injured.
While the war began in Israel's south on Saturday, clashes in the West Bank have intensified over recent days.
The PRCS said that, of the injured, 27 came from live amunition, and eight were caused by rubber bullets.
It also released a statement saying four paramedics had died in Gaza, as a result of air strikes.
While the videos are too graphic to publish, this photo shows colleagues comforting each other on what was another devastating day in the Middle East.
Paramedics console each other in Gaza on Wednesday.
(Supplied: PRCS)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Several protests were held accross the West Bank on Wednesday evening, after another day of bloodshed in the Middle East. I'm in Israel with the ABC team reporting on the war which began on Saturday. In Ramallah, near Jerusalem, a large crowd chanted "Hamas". Further south, in Hebron, men marched through the streets, with some waving the green flag of Hamas. A demonstration was also held in Nablus. This map shows where the gatherings were, in relation to Israel (shaded).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Large protests held in West Bank

children.content: Several protests were held accross the West Bank on Wednesday evening, after another day of bloodshed in the Middle East.
I'm in Israel with the ABC team reporting on the war which began on Saturday.
In Ramallah, near Jerusalem, a large crowd chanted "Hamas".
